Welcome to Noisy Entropy Estimation’s documentation!¶

Analysis/create_df.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Load the results of the analysis into dataframes.

create_df.process_hrate(hrate_dir)¶

Process the hrate results.

Parameters:

hrate_dir (str) – The directory containing the hrate results.

Returns:

The processed dataframe.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

>>> process_hrate('results/hrate')
>>> hrate_data
create_df.process_label(label, label_type)¶

Process a label to get the correct label name.

Parameters:

  • label (str) – The label to process.

  • label_type (str) – The type of label to process.

Returns:

The processed label.

Return type:

str

>>> process_label('0', 'emotion')
create_df.process_multiple_analysis(main_dir, label_type)¶

Process the results of multiple analyses. label_type: - sentiment - topic - emotion - offensive - hate - date - irony - file Return order: - ppm_entropy - ppm_infor_content - ppm_model_order - ppm_distribution - unigram_data - hrate_data

Parameters:

  • main_dir (str) – The directory containing the results of the analyses.

  • label_type (str) – The type of label used for the analyses.

Returns:

A tuple containing the processed dataframes.

Return type:

tuple

>>> process_multiple_analysis('results', 'sentiment')
>>> (ppm_entropy, ppm_infor_content, ppm_model_order, ppm_distribution, unigram_data, hrate_data)
create_df.process_ppm(ppm_dir)¶

Process the ppm results. Return order: - ppm_entropy - ppm_infor_content - ppm_model_order - ppm_distribution

Parameters:

ppm_dir (str) – The directory containing the ppm results.

Returns:

A tuple containing the processed dataframes.

Return type:

tuple

>>> process_ppm('results/ppm')
>>> (ppm_entropy, ppm_infor_content, ppm_model_order, ppm_distribution)
create_df.process_single_analysis(directory)¶

Process the results of a single analysis. Return order: - ppm_entropy - ppm_infor_content - ppm_model_order - ppm_distribution - unigram_data - hrate_data

Parameters:

directory (str) – The directory containing the results of the analysis.

Returns:

A tuple containing the processed dataframes.

Return type:

tuple

>>> process_single_analysis('results/elonmusk')
>>> (ppm_entropy, ppm_infor_content, ppm_model_order, ppm_distribution, unigram_data, hrate_data)
create_df.process_unigrams(unigram_dir)¶

Process the unigrams results.

Parameters:

unigram_dir (str) – The directory containing the unigrams results.

Returns:

The processed dataframe.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

>>> process_unigrams('results/unigrams')
>>> unigram_data

Perform a preliminary analysis of the ppm file.

  • ppm_file (str) – The path to the file containing the ppm.

  • save (bool) – Whether to save the plots or not.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> analyse_ppm('ppm.txt')

Perform a preliminary analysis of the tokens.

  • save (bool) – Whether to save the plots or not.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> analyse_tokens('token.txt')
preliminary_analysis_code.is_punctuation(token)¶

Check if a token is a punctuation symbol.

Parameters:

token (str) – The token to check.

Returns:

True if the token is a punctuation symbol, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

>>> is_punctuation("!")
>>> True
preliminary_analysis_code.is_special_token(token)¶

Check if a token is a special token.

Parameters:

token (str) – The token to check.

Returns:

True if the token is a special token, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

>>> is_special_token("#VAR#")
>>> True
preliminary_analysis_code.plot_token_frequencies(df, vocab_size, save=False)¶

Plot the percentage of tokens that fall into each category.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing the tokens and their frequencies.

  • vocab_size (int) – The size of the vocabulary.

  • save (bool) – Whether to save the plot or not.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> plot_token_frequencies(pd.DataFrame({'token': ['a', 'b', 'c'], 'count': [1, 2, 3]}), 3)
preliminary_analysis_code.run_code_analysis(file, save=False)¶

Run the analysis of the code files.

Parameters:

  • file (str) – The path to the file containing the code.

  • save (bool) – Whether to save the plots or not.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> run_code_analysis('code.csv')

DataAcquisition/dehydrate_tweets.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Dehydrate tweets from a csv file by keeping only tweet_id

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: Directory or CSV file

  • –output, –o: Directory where you want the dehydrated CSV files

Example:
>>> python dehydrate_tweets.py --input data.csv --output dehydrated/
dehydrate_tweets.main()¶

Main function of dehydrate_tweets.py

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> main()
dehydrate_tweets.process_file(fp)¶

Process a csv file with tweet_id and dehydrate it

Parameters:

fp (str) – File path

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> process_file('data.csv')

env.load_env_variable(key, default_value=None, none_allowed=False)¶

Load an environment variable

Parameters:

  • key (str) – key of the environment variable

  • default_value (str) – default value if the environment variable is not found

  • none_allowed (bool) – if the environment variable can be None

Returns:

value of the environment variable

Return type:

str

>>> load_env_variable("TEST", default_value="test")
>>> 'test'

DataAcquisition/hydrate_tweets.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Hydrate tweets from a csv file with tweet_id

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: Directory or CSV file

  • –env: Environment file to get twitter credentials, consumer_key, consumer_secret, access_token, access_token_secret

Example:
>>> python hydrate_tweets.py --input data.csv --env .env

None

Return type:

None

DataAcquisition/run_scraping.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Scraping Twitter with Seleniu and create a csv file with the data.

CLI Arguments:

  • –start, –s: Start date

  • –end, –e: End date (default: today)

  • –interval, –i: Interval (default: 1)

  • –env: Environment file with Chrome driver path and Twitter credentials

  • –from_account, –a: From account

  • –hashtag, –h: Hashtag to search

  • –word, –w: Word to search

  • –headless: Headless mode (default: False)

  • –only_id: Only collect tweet_id (default: False)

Examples:

>>>python3 run_scraping.py –start 2021-01-01 –end 2021-01-31 –env scraping.env –from_account elonmusk >>>python3 run_scraping.py –start 2021-01-01 –end 2021-01-31 –env scraping.env –hashtag bitcoin >>>python3 run_scraping.py –start 2021-01-01 –end 2021-01-31 –env scraping.env –word ukraine

run_scraping.main()¶

Main function of run_scraping.py

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> main()

DataAcquisition/sample_stream.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Script to get a sample of the Twitter stream, using the Twitter API v2. Gather 1% of the real-time stream of Tweets based on a sample of all Tweets. Filter by language and save the data in a csv file.

CLI Arguments:

  • –env: Environment file to get twitter credentials, consumer_key, consumer_secret, access_token, access_token_secret

  • –iter_max: Maximum number of tweets to get per language (Default: 1_000_000)

  • –languages: Languages to keep (Default: en fr es de it)

Examples:

>>>python3 sample_stream.py –env stream.env >>>python3 sample_stream.py –env stream.env –iter_max 1000 –languages en fr

sample_stream.bearer_oauth(r)¶

Method required by bearer token authentication.

Parameters:

r (requests) – request

Returns:

request

Return type:

requests

>>> bearer_oauth(requests)
>>> requests
sample_stream.check_date()¶

Check if the date has changed, if so, close the current csv file and open a new one

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> check_date()
>>> None
sample_stream.connect_to_endpoint(url)¶

Connect to the endpoint and get the data

Parameters:

url (str) – url to connect to

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> connect_to_endpoint('https://api.twitter.com/2/tweets/sample/stream?tweet.fields=lang,created_at&expansions=author_id&user.fields=&place.fields=&media.fields=')
sample_stream.create_url()¶

Create the url to get the sample stream

Returns:

url

Return type:

str

>>> create_url()
>>> 'https://api.twitter.com/2/tweets/sample/stream?tweet.fields=lang,created_at&expansions=author_id&user.fields=&place.fields=&media.fields='
sample_stream.main()¶

Main function of the sample_stream.py script

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> main()

DataAcquisition/scrape_covid_github.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Scrape covid data from github public repository and rehydrate it with twarc

CLI Arguments:

  • –start, –s: Start date for scraping, format YYYY-MM-DD, min 2020-03-22

  • –end, –e: End date for scraping, format YYYY-MM-DD, max 2023-04-12 (Default: 2023-04-12)

  • –env: Environment file to get twitter credentials, consumer_key, consumer_secret, access_token, access_token_secret

  • –max: Max number of tweets to get (Default: 500_000)

  • –languages, –l: Languages to keep (Default: en fr es de it)

Examples:

>>>python3 scrape_covid_github.py –env .env >>>python3 scrape_covid_github.py –start 2020-03-22 –end 2020-03-23 –env .env >>>python3 scrape_covid_github.py –start 2020-03-22 –end 2020-03-23 –max 1000 –env .env

scrape_covid_github.main()¶

Scrape covid data from github public repository and rehydrate it with twarc

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> main()

DataAcquisition/scraping.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

credits:

Scweet: An extensive toolbox to scrape Twitter, written in Python.

description:

Twitter scraping module.

scraping.scraping(since, until=None, words=None, to_account=None, from_account=None, mention_account=None, interval=5, lang=None, headless=True, limit=inf, display_type='Top', resume=False, proxy=None, hashtag=None, save_dir='outputs', filter_replies=False, proximity=False, geocode=None, minreplies=None, minlikes=None, minretweets=None, driver=None, env=None, only_id=False)¶
Function:

Scraping tweets from Twitter.

Parameters:

  • since (str) – date from which we start scraping

  • until (str) – date until which we scrape

  • words (list) – list of words to search for

  • to_account (str) – account to which we search for tweets

  • from_account (str) – account from which we search for tweets

  • mention_account (str) – account to which we search for tweets

  • interval (int) – interval of time between two searches

  • lang (str) – language of the tweets

  • headless (bool) – headless mode

  • limit (int) – limit of tweets to scrape

  • display_type (str) – type of display

  • resume (bool) – resume scraping from previous work

  • proxy (str) – proxy to use

  • hashtag (str) – hashtag to search for

  • save_dir (str) – directory to save the scraped tweets

  • filter_replies (bool) – filter replies

  • proximity (bool) – proximity search

  • geocode (str) – geocode

  • minreplies (int) – minimum number of replies

  • minlikes (int) – minimum number of likes

  • minretweets (int) – minimum number of retweets

  • driver (selenium.webdriver) – driver to use

  • env (str) – environment to use

  • only_id (bool) – only scrape tweet ids

Returns:

scraped tweets

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

>>> scraping(since='2020-01-01', until='2020-01-02', words=['covid', 'corona'], interval=1, save_dir='outputs')
>>> scraping(since='2020-01-01', until='2020-01-02', to_account='@elonmusk', interval=1, save_dir='outputs')

DataAcquisition/utils.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

credits:

Scweet: An extensive toolbox to scrape Twitter, written in Python.

description:

Utility functions for the Twitter scraping.

utils.check_exists_by_xpath(xpath, driver)¶
Function:

Check if an element exists in the page

Parameters:

  • xpath (str) – Xpath of the element

  • driver (selenium.webdriver.chrome.webdriver.WebDriver) – Selenium driver

Returns:

True if the element exists, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

>>> check_exists_by_xpath(xpath, driver)
>>> True
utils.check_for_error(driver)¶
Function:

Check if the page contains an error, or if the rate limit is exceeded

Parameters:

driver (selenium.webdriver.chrome.webdriver.WebDriver) – Selenium driver

Returns:

True if the page contains an error, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

>>> check_for_error(driver)
>>> False
utils.get_data(card, only_id=False)¶
Function:

Extract data from a tweet card, and return it as a tuple

Parameters:

  • card (selenium.webdriver.remote.webelement.WebElement) – Tweet card

  • only_id (bool) – If True, only return the tweet id

Returns:

Tuple containing the tweet id, user id, post date and text

Return type:

tuple

>>> get_data(card)
>>> (123456789, 123456789, '2021-01-01T00:00:00.000Z', 'This is a tweet')
utils.get_last_date_from_csv(path)¶
Function:

Get the last date from a csv file

Parameters:

path (str) – Path to the csv file

Returns:

Last date

Return type:

str

>>> get_last_date_from_csv(path)
>>> '2021-01-01T00:00:00.000Z'
utils.get_metadata(ids, twarc_session)¶
Function:

Get the metadata of the tweets

Parameters:

  • ids (list) – List of tweet ids

  • twarc_session (twarc.Twarc) – Twarc session

Returns:

List of tweets

Return type:

list

>>> get_metadata(ids, twarc_session)
>>> [{'id': 123456789, 'text': 'This is a tweet'}, {'id': 123456789, 'text': 'This is a tweet'}]
utils.get_page(driver, path, retries=3, wait_time=10)¶
Function:

Get a page with retries

Parameters:

  • driver (selenium.webdriver.chrome.webdriver.WebDriver) – Selenium driver

  • path (str) – Path to the page

  • retries (int) – Number of retries

  • wait_time (int) – Time to wait between retries

Returns:

Path to the page

Return type:

str

>>> get_page(driver, path, retries=3, wait_time=10)
>>> 'https://twitter.com/search?q=...'
utils.get_user_id(*args, **kwargs)¶
Function:

Wrapper function for the memoization

Parameters:

  • args (list) – arguments

  • kwargs (dict) – keyword arguments

Returns:

Result of the function

Return type:

any

utils.init_driver(headless=True, proxy=None, show_images=False, option=None, env=None)¶
Function:

Initiate a chromedriver or firefoxdriver instance

Parameters:

  • headless (bool) – If True, run the driver in headless mode

  • proxy (str) – Proxy to use

  • show_images (bool) – If True, show images

  • option (str) – Other option to add

  • env (env.Env) – Environment

Returns:

Selenium driver

Return type:

selenium.webdriver.chrome.webdriver.WebDriver

>>> init_driver(headless=True, proxy=None, show_images=False, option=None, env=None)
>>> <selenium.webdriver.chrome.webdriver.WebDriver (session="123456789")>

EntropyEstimation/entropy.py¶

EntropyEstimation/full_analysis.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Run the full analysis of the entropy estimation project, including unigram entropy estimation, PPM entropy estimation, and Hrate entropy estimation.

CLI Arguments:

  • –tokens, –t: Path to list of tokens

  • –vocab, –v: Path to vocabulary file, if not provided, all tokens will be considered as vocabulary

  • –use_vocab, –uv: Whether to use vocabulary for unigram entropy estimation (default: False)

  • –unigrams, –u: Skip unigram entropy estimation

  • –ppm, –p: Skip PPM entropy estimation

  • –hrate, –h: Skip Hrate entropy estimation

  • –fast, –f: Skip PPM entropy estimation, and uncertainty analysis

  • –output_dir, –o: Path to output directory (default: results/<file_name>)

Examples:
>>> python3 src/entropyEstimation/full_analysis.py --tokens tokens.txt --vocab vocab.txt
>>> python3 src/entropyEstimation/full_analysis.py --tokens tokens.txt --vocab vocab.txt  --fast
>>> python3 src/entropyEstimation/full_analysis.py --tokens tokens.txt --vocab vocab.txt  --unigrams

EntropyEstimation/nse.py¶

nsb_entropy.py

June, 2011 written by Sungho Hong, Computational Neuroscience Unit, Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology May, 2019 updated to Python 3 by Charlie Strauss, Los Alamos National Lab

This script is a python version of Mathematica functions by Christian Mendl implementing the Nemenman-Shafee-Bialek (NSB) estimator of entropy. For the details of the method, check out the references below.

It depends on mpmath and numpy package.

References: http://christian.mendl.net/pages/software.html http://nsb-entropy.sourceforge.net Ilya Nemenman, Fariel Shafee, and William Bialek. Entropy and Inference, Revisited. arXiv:physics/0108025 Ilya Nemenman, William Bialek, and Rob de Ruyter van Steveninck. Entropy and information in neural spike trains: Progress on the sampling problem. Physical Review E 69, 056111 (2004)

nsb.S(nxkx, N, K)¶

Return the estimated entropy. nxkx is the histogram of the input histogram constructed by make_nxkx. N is the total number of samples, and K is the degree of freedom.

>>> from numpy import array
>>> nTest = array([4, 2, 3, 0, 2, 4, 0, 0, 2])
>>> K = 9  # which is actually equal to nTest.size.
>>> S(make_nxkx(nTest, K), nTest.sum(), K)
1.940646728502697166844598206814653716492
nsb.dS(nxkx, N, K)¶

Return the mean squared flucuation of the entropy.

>>> from numpy import array, sqrt
>>> nTest = np.array([4, 2, 3, 0, 2, 4, 0, 0, 2])
>>> K = 9  # which is actually equal to nTest.size.
>>> nxkx = make_nxkx(nTest, K)
>>> s = S(nxkx, nTest.sum(), K)
>>> ds = dS(nxkx, nTest.sum(), K)
>>> ds
3.790453283682443237187782792251041316212
>>> sqrt(ds-s**2) # the standard deviation for the estimated entropy.
0.1560242251518078487118059349690693094484
nsb.make_nxkx(n, K)¶

Return the histogram of the input histogram n assuming that the number of all bins is K.

>>> from numpy import array
>>> nTest = array([4, 2, 3, 0, 2, 4, 0, 0, 2])
>>> make_nxkx(nTest, 9) ==  {0: 3, 2: 3, 3: 1, 4: 2}
True

EntropyEstimation/ppm.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Use PPM entropy estimation to estimate the entropy of a given corpus.

CLI Arguments:

  • –tokens: Path to list of tokens

  • –vocab: Path to list of vocabulary

  • –max_train: Maximum number of training samples to consider

  • –decay: Whether to use the decay version of the algorithm

  • –output_dir: Path to output directory

Examples:
>>> python3 src/entropyEstimation/ppm.py --tokens tokens.txt --vocab vocab.txt
>>> python3 src/entropyEstimation/ppm.py --tokens tokens.txt --vocab vocab.txt --decay
>>> python3 src/entropyEstimation/ppm.py --tokens tokens.txt --vocab vocab.txt --max_train 5000

Preprocessing/clean_code.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Clean code by allowing to detect and remove variables, functions, numbers, strings and comments.

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: Directory or TSV File

  • –lang, –l: Language: Java, Python, C++

  • –debug, –d: Debug, get replacements details in output file (default: False)

  • –var, –v: Keep variables (default: False)

  • –number, –num: Keep numbers (default: False)

  • –comments, –com: Keep comments (default: False)

  • –string, –s: Keep strings (default: False)

Examples:
>>> python clean_code.py --input data.tsv --lang Python
>>> python clean_code.py --input data.tsv --lang Python --debug
>>> python clean_code.py --input data.tsv --lang Python --debug --var --num

clean_code.rm_comments(tokens)¶

Remove comments from a list of tokens and replace them by #COMMENTS#.

Parameters:

tokens (list) – list of tokens

Returns:

list of tokens

Return type:

list

>>> rm_comments(['def', 'hello', '(', ')', ':', '#', 'comment', 'return', '0'])
>>> ['def', 'hello', '(', ')', ':', '#COMMENTS#', 'return', '0']
clean_code.rm_numbers(tokens)¶

Remove numbers from a list of tokens and replace them by #NUM#.

Parameters:

tokens (list) – list of tokens

Returns:

list of tokens

Return type:

list

>>> rm_numbers(['x', '=', '1', '+', '2'])
>>> ['x', '=', '#NUM#', '+', '#NUM#']
clean_code.rm_strings(tokens)¶

Remove strings from a list of tokens and replace them by #STR#.

Parameters:

tokens (list) – list of tokens

Returns:

list of tokens

Return type:

list

>>> rm_strings(['print', '(', '"', 'hello', '"', ')'])
>>> ['print', '(', '#STR#', ')']
clean_code.rm_variables_and_func(tokens)¶

Remove variables and functions from a list of tokens and replace them by #VAR# and #FUNC#.

Parameters:

tokens (list) – list of tokens

Returns:

list of tokens

Return type:

list

>>> rm_variables_and_func(['x', '=', '1', '+', '2'])
>>> ['#VAR#', '=', '1', '+', '2']

Preprocessing/clean_tweets.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Clean Twitter CSV files.

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: Directory containing the raw data, or CSV File

  • –output, –o: Directory to save the scraping-cleaned data.

  • –punctuation, –p: Keep punctuation (default: False)

  • –accents, –a: Keep accents (default: False)

  • –emojis, –e: Keep emojis (default: False)

  • –mentions, –m: Keep mentions (default: False)

  • –urls, –u: Keep urls (default: False)

  • –spaces, –s: Keep extra spaces (default: False)

  • –rt, –r: Keep RT Tags (default: False)

– -lowercase, –l: Keep all cases (default: False)

Examples:
>>> python clean_tweets.py --input data.csv --output data-cleaned
>>> python clean_tweets.py --input data.csv --output data-cleaned --punctuation
>>> python clean_tweets.py --input data.csv --output data-cleaned --punctuation --accents --emojis

Preprocessing/generate_sub_df.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

dsecription:

Generate sub-datasets for a Twitter CSV file. Sub-datasets will be grouped by a column and will contain tweet_id and text columns.

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: CSV file

  • –group-by, –gb: Column to group by

  • –unit, –u: If group-by is “timestamp” choose between “D” (day), “M” (month), “Y” (year)

  • –min-size, –ms: Minimum size of a sub-dataset (default: 100)

Examples:
>>> python generate_sub_df.py --input data.csv --group-by lang
>>> python generate_sub_df.py --input data.csv --group-by timestamp --unit D
>>> python generate_sub_df.py --input data.csv --group-by timestamp --unit D --min-size 1000

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> main()

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> process_file('data.csv')

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Label a Twitter CSV file by adding a class column.

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: CSV file or directory

  • –class_, –c: Class to labelled the data

Examples:
>>> python labelled_data.py --input data.csv --class_ 1

Preprocessing/tokenize_code.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Tokenize a Programming Language CSV file.

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: CSV file or directory

  • –char, –c: Character-level tokenization (default: False)

  • –ngrams, –n: Generate n-grams (default: 1)

Examples:
>>> python tokenize_code.py --input data.csv
>>> python tokenize_code.py --input data.csv --char
>>> python tokenize_code.py --input data.csv --ngrams 3
>>> python tokenize_code.py --input data.csv --char --ngrams 3
tokenize_code.generate_ngrams(tokens, n)¶

Generate n-grams from a list of tokens.

Parameters:

  • tokens (list) – list of tokens

  • n (int) – n-gram size

Returns:

list of n-grams

Return type:

list

>>> generate_ngrams(['def', 'main', '(', ')', ':', 'return', '0'], 3)
>>> ['def main (', 'main ( )', '( ) :', ') : return', ': return 0']
tokenize_code.main()¶

Main function of the tokenize_code.py script.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> main()

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> process_file('data.csv')

Process a CSV file by chunks and generate tokens and vocab files.

  • fp (str) – CSV file

  • num_lines (int) – number of lines

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

>>> process_file_chunk('data.csv', 100_000)

Preprocessing/tokenize_tweets.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Tokenize a Twitter CSV file.

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: Directory or CSV File

  • –ngrams, –n: Generate n-grams (default: 1)

  • –chars, –c: Use characters instead of words (default: False)

Examples:
>>> python tokenize_tweets.py --input data
>>> python tokenize_tweets.py --input data --ngrams 2
>>> python tokenize_tweets.py --input data --ngrams 2 --chars
tokenize_tweets.generate_ngrams(tokens, n)¶

Generate n-grams from a list of tokens.

Parameters:

  • tokens (list) – list of tokens

  • n (int) – n-gram

Returns:

list of n-grams

Return type:

list

>>> generate_ngrams(['I', 'am', 'so', 'happy'], 2)
>>> ['I am', 'am so', 'so happy']

Preprocessing/tokenize_text.py¶

author:

Siméon FEREZ

version:

1.0.0

copyright:

Copyright © 2023 by Siméon FEREZ. All rights reserved. This work may not be reproduced, in whole or in part, without the written permission of the author.

description:

Tokenize the raw linguistic data txt files.

CLI Arguments:

  • –input, –i: Directory or txt file

  • –ngrams, –n: Generate n-grams (default: 1)

  • –chars, –c: Use characters instead of words (default: False)

Examples:
>>> python tokenize_text.py --input data.txt
>>> python tokenize_text.py --input data.txt --ngrams 2
>>> python tokenize_text.py --input data.txt --ngrams 2 --chars
tokenize_text.generate_ngrams(tokens, n)¶

Generate n-grams from a list of tokens.

Parameters:

  • tokens (list) – list of tokens

  • n (int) – n-gram

Returns:

list of n-grams

Return type:

list

>>> generate_ngrams(['I', 'am', 'so', 'happy'], 2)
>>> ['I am', 'am so', 'so happy']
